thread.title: Tributes pour in as former Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup hero Paul McCarthy dies suddenly aged 45
thread.title_full: Tributes pour in as former Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup hero Paul McCarthy dies suddenly aged 45

author: Jim Daly
title: Tributes pour in as former Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup hero Paul McCarthy dies suddenly aged 45
text:
Sport Tributes pour in as former Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup hero Paul McCarthy dies suddenly aged 45 The former Republic of Ireland under-21 international was part of the Chairboys team that went on a fairytale run and reached the FA Cup semi-finals in 2001 Share Former Wycombe star Paul McCarthy has died suddenly ages 45 (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Share Get football   Could   
Former Wycombe Wanderers FA Cup hero Paul McCarthy has died suddenly aged 45. 
Former Republic of Ireland under-21 international was part of the Chairboys team that went on a fairytale run and reached the FA Cup semi-finals in 2001. 
They were narrowly beaten 2-1 by Liverpool at the last four stage. 
He also scored in the famous quarter-final win against Leicester at Filbert Street - probably the club's greatest ever moment. 
The Cork native played for a number of other English clubs, including Brighton. 
McCarthy began his career at the Seagulls and made over 200 appearances on the South Coast before moving to Adams Park in 1996, where five years later he helped the team embark on that famous cup run. 
He also played alongside Roy Keane at underage level with Rockmount AFC. Wycombe Wanderers players celebrate their victory at Leicester in 2001 
He later played for Oxford United, Hornchurch and Ebbsfleet United, where he lifted the FA Trophy at Wembley in 2008. 
Ebbsfleet released a statement, saying: ""Quite apart from going down in Fleet history as the man who lifted the Trophy at Wembley in 2008, Paul was a well-loved and popular figure throughout his long association with the club. 
"All of us at the club, many of whom will remember working alongside Paul in his time here, are deeply saddened by the news and extend our most heartfelt sympathies to his family at this time as we're sure do all the club's fans who remember him warmly as a person and a great servant at Stonebridge Road." 
A number of his other former clubs also paid tribute to him online. 
Brighton tweeted: "Very sad news reaching us this morning that former BHAFC, Wycombe and Oxford defender Paul McCarthy died suddenly yesterday aged just 45." 
Wycombe added: "We are deeply saddened to hear that Paul McCarthy - a hero of our 2000/01 FA Cup run - has died at the age of only 45." 
Oxford, where McCarthy played 35 times first on loan and then permanently, tweeted: "Very sad news that former U's defender Paul McCarthy has died aged just 45. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family ." 
Players who lined up alongside McCarthy also paid tribute to him, with former Wycbome team-mate Richard Harris saying: " I just heard the sad news about my old team mate Paul McCarthy 'Macca'. My thoughts & prayers go out to his family. RIP" 
Mark Rodgers who also played with McCarthy at Adams Park, said: "So terribly sad to hear of the passing of @ wwfcofficial teammate Paul McCarthy. Such a great guy. Thoughts are with his family. RIP Macca." 
Matt Lawrence added: "Absolutely devastated about the news of the passing of Paul McCarthy: teammate, driving partner and all around top man." 
The cause of the former Republic of Ireland Under-21 international's death has not yet been disclosed. Like us on Facebook
